Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Make search collapsible" (#9614) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I made the advanced search collapsible on narrow screens.

Before:

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/58230697/7be0bf38-cb88-44b4-8a75-c12148666866)


After:

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/58230697/b8f08692-94ed-46f8-9d34-5dba8549ba63)

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/58230697/8cc48514-f149-46b9-8d93-e55091c6c947)

There are details in the problem description that I didn't change (removing sort-by and putting filters below packages returned) because I talked with PM and designers and we didn't find these changes useful.

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9374ery/issues/123

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.exe and NuGet Packages Support Policy" (#9612) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Silent failure on submitting package through UI when it was published concurrently with API" (#9611) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

There is no feedback on failing to publish package on "verify package" page when package that is being published already exists.

### Repro Steps

1. Prepare a new package;
2. Create an API key that would allow publishing the package from step 1;
3. Log into Gallery, go to upload page, pick the prepared .nupkg file there. You should end up on "verify package" page. DO NOT click "Submit" there yet.
4. Push the package file from command line using the API key from step 2. Package should publish fine.
5. Go back to the browser and click "Submit".

Notice that the page reloads without any feedback on what happened.

The request sent on clicking "submit" responds with HTTP 500.

### Expected Behavior

An error is displayed saying the package already exists.

### Screenshots

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/102933/76567824-37a5-467f-900a-e2c3a70925b6)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Readme reference image contained in package" (#9610) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

While readme file needs to be contained in package, image files referenced from readme cannot.

### The Elevator Pitch

Readme should either be fully self-contained or fully external to a package.

### Additional Context and Details

Trying to reference an image contained within the nuget package itself using a relative url, I get the following error: 

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/13473229/e1e464df-ebf1-4a20-8873-ff28428baa7f)

As of my current understanding, images may only be referenced using absolute URL as of [trusted domains](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/package-readme-on-nuget-org#allowed-domains-for-images-and-badges). Being able to include and reference images within the package itself would allow a readme to be self-contained, making it more robust as being independent from external changes. External information may need to be changed/updated for newer version while information for an existing package should remain unchanged as is true with any other asset contained in the package.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Usability]Search Results are difficult to navigate" (#9608) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copies from: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1853049/

Steps to reproduce:
Task 7: Search for packages

BL1 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Professional Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1555), Chrome Version 114.0.5735.110
Screen Reader: JAWS Professional Edition Version 2023.2212.23

BL2 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Home Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1848), Microsoft Edge version 116.0.1908.0
Screen Reader: NVDA version 2023.1

Issue Details:
Participant was uncertain where second result started. He stated that these results would be better in a tabular form.
Participant stated that each search result should be a heading, which would allow her to navigate to each result easily.

Recommendation:
Consider showing results in a table that would allow the advantages of table navigation for screen reader users.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Usability]Package Details Tabs read as collapsed" (#9607) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1853052/

Steps to reproduce:
Task 8: View package details

BL1 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Professional Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1555), Chrome Version 114.0.5735.110
Screen Reader: JAWS Professional Edition Version 2023.2212.23

BL2 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Home Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1848), Microsoft Edge version 116.0.1908.0
Screen Reader: NVDA version 2023.1

Issue Details:
Participant doesn’t like the fact that all the tabs, except Readme, are collapsed even when selected.
Participant noted that the tabs read as “collapsed” when selected

Recommendation:
Consider by default, expanding a tab’s content when that tab is selected.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: add ability to filter deprecated results in nuget.org search " (#9606) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

At the moment if searching for Microsoft.AspNetCore.Razor a lot of results come up as deprecated but some are still alive and well. 

Be useful to filter out deprecated packages and probably should be the default. 

### The Elevator Pitch

Filter out deprecated results by default will mean users won’t use deprecated packages by mistake. 

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CPM: PackageVersion metadata should be copied to PackageReference items" (#12801) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

MSBuild.exe

### Current Behavior

- When using the NuGet Central Package Management feature, if additional metadata is defined on the `PackageVersion` item it is not copied to the corresponding `PackageReference`. I am specifically interested in the `PrivateAssets` metadata. I realize that the `PackageReference` can specify this, but it easier to do this in the global package `.props` file instead of requiring all projects to specify it.

### Desired Behavior

Any metadata specified on the `PackageVersion` item should be copied to the corresponding `PackageReference` item. If the `PackageReference` already contains a value for the specified metadata then it should probably take precedence over the global value.

### Additional Context

The [Microsoft.Build.CentralPackageVersions](https://github.com/microsoft/MSBuildSdks/tree/main/src/CentralPackageVersions) implementation handled this without issue because it relied on using `<PackageReference Update="xyz" />` instead of mapping a different item.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet warnings and errors for non-SDK PackageReference projects disappear from VS's error list" (#12800) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

VS17.7

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Create a .NET Framework (non-SDK style) project, and using PackageReference as the package format, install NuGet.Protocol version 6.6.0, and Newtonsoft.Json 9.0.1.

The first time you try to build, you'll see a NU1605 warning in the Error List.  Try to build a second time, and the NU1605 disappears. Closing the project and reloading it will add it to the Error List again after the first restore/build, until the second time you build.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Cross-platform sign Verify] The expected error/warning disappeared after restoring the project on Mac" (#11940) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.3.0.102

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

## Repro steps
1. Git clone [https://github.com/NuGet/Entropy.git](https://github.com/NuGet/Entropy.git)
2. Set the following parameters in “pathOnUnix.ps1” file:
    a. The SDK channel must be: 6.0.4xx
    b. The SDK version should be:  latest
    c. Add a -Quality/--quality argument with a value of: signed
3. Cd /home/nuget/Desktop/SDKPatchTool/ and type in command './patchOnUnix.ps1'
4. Create a new test certificate: ` .\CreateTestCertificate.ps1 -AddAsTrustedRootAuthority -Password password -GenerateCerFile`
5. Sign a package:` NuGet.exe sign <PackageFilePath> -CertificatePath <PfxFilePath>` on NuGet path.
6. Copy the.pfx file/.cer file and signed package from the above Windows machine to Mac machine.
7. Add the certificate to trusted store: 
`sudo security add-trusted-cert -d -r trustRoot -k "/Library/KeyChains/System.keychain" "<cerFilePath>"`
8. Trusted Certificate:  
     a. Copy the PFX file to your Mac machine.
    b. Open a Terminal window and execute:
    `    openssl pkcs12 -in <PfxFilePath> -out <PemFilePath> -nokeys`
        When prompted, enter the PFX password.
    c. Open the PEM file created in step 3.
   d. Copy the entire block labelled with BEGIN CERTIFICATE/END CERTIFICATE:
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
…
-----END CERTIFICATE-----

  e. In the versioned directory of your patched .NET SDK open ./trustedroots/codesignctl.pem.
  f. At the end of the file on a new blank line, paste the copied certificate in PEM format.
  g. Save the file.

8. Create a project, add package reference in the .csproj file
```
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="<packageName>" Version="<packageVersion>" />
  </ItemGroup>
```
9. Add the feed (path contains the signed package), set required mode in nuget.config file with trusted signers list:
  ```
  <packageSources>
      <add key="<anyname>" value="<signed package parent folder>" />
     <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" protocolVersion="3" />
   </packageSources>
   <config>
    <add key="signatureValidationMode" value="require" />
   </config>
  <trustedSigners>
     <author name="JamieZhang">       
         <certificate fingerprint="AAAAA" hashAlgorithm="SHA256" allowUntrustedRoot="false" />
     </author>
  </trustedSigners>
```
10. Clear the cache: <patchedSDKPath>`./dotnet nuget locals all –clear`.
11. Delete the <projectPath>/obj folder if there is any.
12. Set the envrioment:
  `export DOTNET_NUGET_SIGNATURE_VERIFICATION=true`
13. Go inside the project folder, verify the package by running restore: <patchedSDKPath>`./dotnet restore <projectpath>/<projectname>.csproj`

## Expected
The expected error/warning should show after restoring the project.

## Actual
The expected error/warning disappeared after restoring the project.


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

NuGet.Configuration.PackageSourceUpdateOptions.UpdateEnabled.get -> bool
static readonly NuGet.Configuration.PackageSourceUpdateOptions.Default -> NuGet.Configuration.PackageSourceUpdateOptions

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget restore fails  with Error NU3003: The package signature is invalid or cannot be verified on this platform." (#12760) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

MSBuild version = "17.2.0+41abc5629"

### Worked before?

worked with xunit 2.4.2

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Updated the xunit package from 2.4.2 to the latest 2.5.0 (https://www.nuget.org/packages/xunit.core/2.5.0)
2. Queued a new build on our pipeline and nuget restore fails with the below error on windows only, restore is successful on mac and linux: error NU3003: Package 'xunit.runner.visualstudio 2.5.0' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The package signature is invalid or cannot be verified on this platform.
3. Below id the ado results with verbose logs:
https://mssqltools.visualstudio.com/CrossPlatBuildScripts/_build/results?buildId=206872&view=logs&j=b2ceb7fa-76eb-5e2f-7afb-5c7fcf0ef065&t=e83f30b7-a2bb-5f3b-7eb9-2f82380d0d78

### Verbose Logs

```shell
https://mssqltools.visualstudio.com/CrossPlatBuildScripts/_build/results?buildId=206872&view=logs&j=b2ceb7fa-76eb-5e2f-7afb-5c7fcf0ef065&t=e83f30b7-a2bb-5f3b-7eb9-2f82380d0d78&l=5
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023" (#70) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023.  If you validate that packages are author signed by Microsoft using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages) or the [`verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, you will need to take steps to avoid disruptions when installing Microsoft packages signed with the new certificate.

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blog post on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/microsoft-author-signing-certificate-update-2023/

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The Microsoft author signing certificate will be updated as soon as November 1st, 2020" (#47) at NuGet/Announcements
Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability" (#69) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET and NuGet on Linux. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET 7.0 and NuGet(nuget.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement) where a potential race condition that can lead to a symlink attack on Linux. Non-Linux platforms are not affected. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12653 ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software This issue only affects Linux systems. ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.6.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.5.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.4.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.3.2 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.2.3 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.0.4 version or earlier. [GitHub Advisory](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/security/advisories/GHSA-6qmf-mmc7-6c2p) ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET SDK 7.0.106 or earlier, or 7.0.303 or earlier - Any .NET SDK 6.0.117 or earlier, or 6.0.312 or earlier, or 6.0.409 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet package or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.PackageManagement versions). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.6.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.6.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.6.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.5.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.5.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.5.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.4.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.4.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.4.2/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.3.2 or lower, you should download and install 6.3.3 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.3.3/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.3 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.4 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.4/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.4 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.5/nuget.exe. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the `nuget` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` - If you're using .NET 7.0, you should download and install Runtime 7.0.7 or SDK 7.0.107 or SDK 7.0.304 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/7.0. - If you're using .NET 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.18 or SDK 6.0.118 or SDK 6.0.312 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed self-contained applications targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0, please email details to secure@microsoft.com. Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at . ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client . The Announcements repo will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind.
